title: Courteney Cox cuddles up to Kaley Cuoco during girls' night out
text:
They starred in some of the biggest sitcoms in TV history.

Big Bang Theory and Friends fans rejoiced after learning Courteney Cox, 55, had enjoyed a girls' get together with Kaley Cuoco, 33.

The ladies posted a delightful and cuddly snap from their escapades onto Instagram on Sunday.

Double trouble! Courteney Cox and Kaley Cuoco got sitcom fans rejoicing after posting a snap from their girls' get together on Sunday

Referencing their TV shows, Couteney captioned the snap, 'Big Bang Friends.'

In the snap, Courteney cosied up to the Big Bang Theory actress as she posed with puckered up lips.

Kaley posted the exact same snap to her account, along with the caption, 'My friend (heart emoticon).'

Based on the smiles on their faces, it definitely looked like quite the fun night out.

All's well that ends well: Cuoco played actress Penny in the beloved sitcom The Big Bang Theory, which recently went off the air

Man and wife! Cuoco tied the knot with Karl Cook in 2018

It's been just a few months since The Big Bang Theory went off the air forever, and Kaley seems to be making the most of her newfound free time.

Whether she is horse riding or enjoying time with her husband Karl Cook, the actress has been documenting it all on her Instagram account.

Meanwhile, Courteney has been back in the spotlight after her hit series Friends celebrated it's 25th anniversary.

Friends forever: Meanwhile, Courteney has been back in the spotlight after her hit series Friends celebrated it's 25th anniversary

The actress played the Type A Monica Gellar, who went on to marry Chandler Bing (Matthew Perry).

Though the couple ended up married with kids, it was recently revealed the beloved pairing was never meant to happen in the first place.

As revealed in the new book Generation Friends, the couple were supposed to get together for one night only.

But writers decided to allow the relationship to evolve after filming the scene in front of a live audience.

'The cheers and hoots of delight went on and on, drowning out the performers and shaking the room,' author Saul Austerlitz wrote.
